moves.1. e4 d5 2. exd5 Nf6 3. Nf3 e6 4. dxe6: White omits here Bb4+, his best repy.
moves.4... Bxe6 5. Be2 c6: I decided to go for a simple developement line.
moves.6. d3 Bd6 7. h3: Play this only if forced to, and better as a response than profilactic... anyway, it's in white's agenda.
moves.7... h6: ...so is this one. In fact, Ng5 is a nasty threat: I can't allow Ne6 to be exchanged by the N, leaving a poor pawn there.
moves.8. O-O Qc7 9. Nbd2 Nbd7: White is slow in developement, so I can reach one by one all my agenda's moves.
moves.10. Re1 O-O-O: I will suffer from a white pawn's storm, but - specially in this white line - this will take more time than my own attack.
moves.11. Nf1: Interesting defensive move, opening the way for the dsb. This will be slow, so let's speed it up!
moves.11... g5: White liked to play as black, and his desire is honoured.
moves.12. Nf3h2: Another good defensive move, that makes me wonder how to break in. My pawns have to advance further, under the fire of white's B. I need h5 to prevent a piece to land on g4, to make impossible for white to play h5 (blocking the column) and assuring that g5 would have openend the column. I can't avoid right now his pieces to go to g5: the only thing I can do is to sac the g pawn (12... g5) and only after play Rg8, h5 etc. It was a blitz, so...
moves.12... Rdg8: I can play h5 now, but I am allowing...
moves.13. Ng4 h5 14. Nxf6 Nxf6: h5 goal, reached. Now, before g4, I have to push to h4, as before...
moves.15. Bd2: White leaves it to me... well... it does threat something, I overlooked.
moves.15... h4 16. Bc3: The normal move is Rh6, and it is probably the only and the best.
moves.16... Qd8: My force on h2 is not really useful right now. Still, a horrible move.
moves.17. Bxf6: ...but my opponent made it a good one. Now my Q is again on an active spot, looking to f2.
moves.17... Qxf6 18. Bg4: ...and this is the price for my premature h4. Now I am under pressure, and I have to be very calm to defend. My Q on f6 comes to be a real annoyance, blocking my f pawn when needed.
moves.18... Rge8: My attack being blocked, my R has to return to duty.
moves.19. Bxe6+: White is happy with exchanging down and go to the endgame.
moves.19... Rxe6 20. Qg4 Rhe8 21. c3: I wouldn't have taken the pawn: white correctly spotted Bc5, my next move, attacking f2. In this way, he prevents it.
moves.22. Rxe6 Rxe6 23. Ne3: This N goes to f5, he wants to take my B. I don't want to take it off the diag so easily.
moves.23... Qg6: Threat on d3 pending after the N jumps.
moves.24. Qf5: I can play this, but I won't exchange Q so easily. Just let me rearrange.
moves.24... Qg7 25. Kf1: This is a plain loss of tempo, and besides, it gives me chances.
moves.26. Qa5+: This is nasty, too. If Kb8, Qd8# If b6, Qxh7+.
moves.26... Kc8 27. Ng4: I should have sacrified on g5 before, no doubt. This square is my nightmare...
moves.29. Qe3: Qe8+, Kc7 leaves WQ just hanging over there. If Re1 is not played, of course.
moves.29... Qf5: Increasing my pressure on f2. What else?
moves.30. Re1 Kc7: No check if the Q leaves, and Qxd3+ would follow.
moves.31. f3: Solving his f2 problem at the cost of g3 for my lsb. Take note.
moves.31... Ra4: This is not to attack the pawn, but to make room for my B. Of course, I can't move it there now, or checks will start. But...
moves.32. a3 Ra5: White should be able to win this by pushing those pawns, but I have to hope for a weakness.
moves.33... Rb5: Just inviting him to block my R with b4. Maybe I should have gone c5 instead.
moves.34. Re2: Wow! Look well to this move, and try to understand why this is a blunder.
moves.34... Qb1+: This seems to be a naive check, but after Re1, Qxb7, winning a pawn and opening the way for a massive penetration. White saw all that, and unfortunately played the alternate move too quickly, allowing a splendid...
moves.35. Kf2 Bg3#: ...mate! I hope you enjoyed this one. White made some mistake (so did I!), but overall he played very intelligent defensive moves in many occasions, don't falling in easy traps.
